border-style: solid; margin: 4px;" /></a></div><p>Loudon County Schools is demonstrating what's needed to implement and sustain improvement in teacher practice.</p></description><pubDate>Thu, 05 Mar 2015 13:24:00 -0800</pubDate><numberOfComments>0</numberOfComments><author>Linda  Jacobson</author><postImage type="rollup">http://www.impatientoptimists.org/~/media/Blog/Images/BlogPosts/List-Archive-Thumbnail/M/MJ-MO/mm398649468708d54b8499aa4a273d899783e75__autocropped_lat_autocropped.jpg?w=110</postImage><topic>College-Ready Education (U.S.)</topic><program>Education</program></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">{16D5831A-DB8E-4351-B800-D2244CFB1147}</guid><link>http://www.impatientoptimists.org/Posts/2015/02/Focus-on-Teachers-Teacher-Strategies-for-Personalized-Learning</link><a10:author><a10:name>Vicki Phillips</a10:name></a10:author><title>Focus on Teachers: Teacher Strategies for Personalized Learning</title><description><div style="text-align: left; border-style: solid; margin: 4px;" /></a></div><p>BetterLesson is making effective blended practice available to every educator in the world.</p></description><pubDate>Wed, 25 Feb 2015 15:55:54 -0800</pubDate><numberOfComments>0</numberOfComments><author>Vicki Phillips</author><postImage type="rollup">http://www.impatientoptimists.org/~/media/Blog/Images/BlogPosts/List-Archive-Thumbnail/B/Other/b0c34db15e9b44fe89aa699ef1558a98epng_png_autocropped_lat_autocropped.jpg?w=110</postImage><topic>College-Ready Education (U.S.)</topic><program>Education</program></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">{E1820B2E-8A41-4571-A73E-AD1C2152B2A2}</guid><link>http://www.impatientoptimists.org/Posts/2015/02/Letting-Down-Our-Walls-with-Tools-That-Spark-Collaboration</link><a10:author><a10:name>Lucy  Hood</a10:name></a10:author><title>\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdLetting Down Our Walls\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd with Tools That Spark Collaboration</title><description><div style="text-align: left; "><a href="http://www.impatientoptimists.org/Posts/2015/02/Letting-Down-Our-Walls-with-Tools-That-Spark-Collaboration"><img src="http://www.impatientoptimists.org/~/media/Blog/Images/BlogPosts/List-Archive-Thumbnail/C/CA-CE/ca373523c6a69825b9a44ffb3d9a83f0459e782__autocropped_lat_autocropped.jpg?w=110" style="border-width: 0px; border-style: solid; margin: 4px;" /></a></div><p>How teachers and school leaders restructured faculty meetings to focus more on classroom instruction.</p></description><pubDate>Thu, 05 Feb 2015 14:02:25 -0800</pubDate><numberOfComments>0</numberOfComments><author>Lucy  Hood</author><postImage type="rollup">http://www.impatientoptimists.org/~/media/Blog/Images/BlogPosts/List-Archive-Thumbnail/C/CA-CE/ca373523c6a69825b9a44ffb3d9a83f0459e782__autocropped_lat_autocropped.jpg?w=110</postImage><topic>College-Ready Education (U.S.)</topic><program>Education</program></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">{3945F131-A972-46FE-99B2-D1067CD03F56}</guid><link>http://www.impatientoptimists.org/Posts/2015/02/Education-Connections-A-Onestop-Resource-Network-for-Busy-ELL-Teachers</link><a10:author><a10:name>Lisa Rosenthal</a10:name></a10:author><title>Education Connections: A One-stop Resource Network for Busy ELL Teachers</title><description><div style="text-align: left; "><a href="http://www.impatientoptimists.org/Posts/2015/02/Education-Connections-A-Onestop-Resource-Network-for-Busy-ELL-Teachers"><img src="http://www.impatientoptimists.org/~/media/Blog/Images/BlogPosts/List-Archive-Thumbnail/M/MJ-MO/mm39860fbc523bcfaea427e8fa5d84c98546dee__autocropped_list_post_autocropped.jpg?w=110" style="border-width: 0px; border-style: solid; margin: 4px;" /></a></div><p>On the Education Connections website, teachers can find help on implementing the Common Core State Standards for ELLs and differentiating instruction based on a student\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds native language, culture, and learning difficulties.</p></description><pubDate>Thu, 05 Feb 2015 13:56:29 -0800</pubDate><numberOfComments>0</numberOfComments><author>Lisa Rosenthal</author><postImage type="rollup">http://www.impatientoptimists.org/~/media/Blog/Images/BlogPosts/List-Archive-Thumbnail/M/MJ-MO/mm39860fbc523bcfaea427e8fa5d84c98546dee__autocropped_list_post_autocropped.jpg?w=110</postImage><topic>College-Ready Education (U.S.)</topic><program>Education</program></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">{89A84B3E-5402-40CB-A7DA-2CE2073F34F8}</guid><link>http://www.impatientoptimists.org/Posts/2015/02/Solving-for-Skilled-Algebra-Instruction</link><a10:author><a10:name>Linda  Jacobson</a10:name></a10:author><title>Solving for Skilled Algebra Instruction</title><description><div style="text-align: left; "><a href="http://www.impatientoptimists.org/Posts/2015/02/Solving-for-Skilled-Algebra-Instruction"><img src="http://www.impatientoptimists.org/~/media/Blog/Images/BlogPosts/List-Archive-Thumbnail/M/MF-MI/mh411176f4ef8ea283f4f39a083ec1c3337bc7e__autocropped_lat_autocropped.jpg?w=110" style="border-width: 0px; border-style: solid; margin: 4px;" /></a></div><p>Algebra Nation is becoming an online community of teachers who are supporting each other in shifting their instructional practices to meet the Common Core math standards.</p></description><pubDate>Thu, 05 Feb 2015 13:50:06 -0800</pubDate><numberOfComments>0</numberOfComments><author>Linda  Jacobson</author><postImage type="rollup">http://www.impatientoptimists.org/~/media/Blog/Images/BlogPosts/List-Archive-Thumbnail/M/MF-MI/mh411176f4ef8ea283f4f39a083ec1c3337bc7e__autocropped_lat_autocropped.jpg?w=110</postImage><topic>College-Ready Education (U.S.)</topic><program>Education</program></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">{3B76CB63-EF7B-4349-9CE7-19BD315DA1AD}</guid><link>http://www.impatientoptimists.org/Posts/2015/02/Changing-Faces-Continued-Progress</link><a10:author><a10:name>Vicki Phillips</a10:name></a10:author><title>Changing Faces, Continued Progress</title><description><div style="text-align: left; border-style: solid; margin: 4px;" /></a></div><p>Mary Ellen Elia's commitment to Hillsborough County, Florida. </p></description><pubDate>Wed, 04 Feb 2015 16:29:42 -0800</pubDate><numberOfComments>0</numberOfComments><author>Vicki Phillips</author><postImage type="rollup">http://www.impatientoptimists.org/~/media/Blog/Images/BlogPosts/List-Archive-Thumbnail/E/EJ-EO/ek18277879ed4a55a0b48ec90ed4df1459ef5c8__autocropped_lat_autocropped.jpg?w=110</postImage><topic>College-Ready Education (U.S.)</topic><program>Education</program></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">{E5A65813-0A6C-4638-BBF9-BC5F725F15BD}</guid><link>http://www.impatientoptimists.org/Posts/2015/02/Ask-the-Teachers</link><a10:author><a10:name>Vicki Phillips</a10:name></a10:author><title>Ask the Teachers!</title><description><div style="text-align: left; border-style: solid; margin: 4px;" /></a></div><p>Last week in a speech at BETT 2015, I spoke about personalized learning for students and strengthening the teacher-student connection in the age of technology.</p></description><pubDate>Mon, 02 Feb 2015 12:56:01 -0800</pubDate><numberOfComments>0</numberOfComments><author>Vicki Phillips</author><postImage type="rollup">http://www.impatientoptimists.org/~/media/Blog/Images/BlogPosts/List-Archive-Thumbnail/A/AP-AZ/ask-the-teacher5a88bcea85c24e64a9f77954d658310cpng_png_autocropped_lat_autocropped.jpg?w=110</postImage><topic>College-Ready Education (U.S.)</topic><program>Education</program></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">{1F381068-5806-4B8A-AD81-5E1432ED6DBB}</guid><link>http://www.impatientoptimists.org/Posts/2015/01/5-Reasons-Were-Optimistic-about-US-Schools</link><a10:author><a10:name>Allan Golston</a10:name></a10:author><title>5 Reasons I\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdm Optimistic about U.S. Schools</title><description><div style="text-align: left; "><a href="http://www.impatientoptimists.org/Posts/2015/01/5-Reasons-Were-Optimistic-about-US-Schools"><img src="http://www.impatientoptimists.org/~/media/Blog/Images/BlogPosts/List-Archive-Thumbnail/M/MF-MI/mh439347c1b83985e91417d8c638cda306c2da1__autocropped_lat_autocropped.jpg?w=110" style="border-width: 0px; border-style: solid; margin: 4px;" /></a></div><p>How education can help increase opportunities for all young people in the United States.</p></description><pubDate>Wed, 21 Jan 2015 21:27:44 -0800</pubDate><numberOfComments>0</numberOfComments><author>Allan Golston</author><postImage type="rollup">http://www.impatientoptimists.org/~/media/Blog/Images/BlogPosts/List-Archive-Thumbnail/M/MF-MI/mh439347c1b83985e91417d8c638cda306c2da1__autocropped_lat_autocropped.jpg?w=110</postImage><topic>Postsecondary Education|College-Ready Education (U.S.)</topic><program>Education</program></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">{C8A913F9-31AD-4D62-9A43-FD12CFBBF955}</guid><link>http://www.impatientoptimists.org/Posts/2015/01/3-MustHaves-for-Every-Child</link><a10:author><a10:name>Sue Desmond-Hellmann</a10:name></a10:author><title>3 Must-Haves for Every Child</title><description><div style="text-align: left; "><a href="http://www.impatientoptimists.org/Posts/2015/01/3-MustHaves-for-Every-Child"><img src="http://www.impatientoptimists.org/~/media/Blog/Images/BlogPosts/List-Archive-Thumbnail/S/SP-SZ/sue-cove324d2d73f9b74dd7a491ec1f688d0497__autocropped_lat_autocropped.jpg?w=110" style="border-width: 0px; border-style: solid; margin: 4px;" /></a></div><p>Whether it's glopbal or local, there are a few things that every child needs to lead a healthy, productive life: A stable place to call home; Good schools, with highly qualified teachers; Strong communities that foster a sense of opportunity.</p></description><pubDate>Mon, 12 Jan 2015 07:31:32 -0800</pubDate><numberOfComments>0</numberOfComments><author>Sue Desmond-Hellmann</author><postImage type="rollup">http://www.impatientoptimists.org/~/media/Blog/Images/BlogPosts/List-Archive-Thumbnail/S/SP-SZ/sue-cove324d2d73f9b74dd7a491ec1f688d0497__autocropped_lat_autocropped.jpg?w=110</postImage><topic>Pacific Northwest Community|College-Ready Education (U.S.)|Family Homelessness (U.S.)</topic><program>Education</program></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">{371D2E2D-58CD-40C6-BD7C-E4735A69975B}</guid><link>http://www.impatientoptimists.org/Posts/2015/01/Next-Gen-Learning-Is-Gaining-Traction</link><a10:author><a10:name>Andy Calkins</a10:name></a10:author><title>Next Gen Learning Is Gaining Traction</title><description><div style="text-align: left; "><a href="http://www.impatientoptimists.org/Posts/2015/01/Next-Gen-Learning-Is-Gaining-Traction"><img src="http://www.impatientoptimists.org/~/media/Blog/Images/BlogPosts/List-Archive-Thumbnail/B/BJ-BO/bk41412a22aad13d04245039897070f77bc0898__autocropped_lat_autocropped.jpg?w=110" style="border-width: 0px; border-style: solid; margin: 4px;" /></a></div><p>Don\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdt look now, but\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd next-generation learning is gaining traction.</p></description><pubDate>Wed, 07 Jan 2015 20:26:52 -0800</pubDate><numberOfComments>0</numberOfComments><author>Andy Calkins</author><postImage type="rollup">http://www.impatientoptimists.org/~/media/Blog/Images/BlogPosts/List-Archive-Thumbnail/B/BJ-BO/bk41412a22aad13d04245039897070f77bc0898__autocropped_lat_autocropped.jpg?w=110</postImage><topic>College-Ready Education (U.S.)</topic><program>Education</program></item></channel></rss>
